job_title: Director of IT in Draper, UT
pros: Excellent culture. Pivots quickly ensuring relevance. Faculty, staff, and administration model mission, vision, and values every day. The university cares deeply about its students and their professional success as caregivers and providers. The organization "walks the walk."
cons: Typical growing pains associated with a fast-moving organization. Process improvement could strengthen operations. To properly scale sometimes means having to slow things down so that outputs are more fully baked. There have been some heavy sunk costs associated with academic programs that didn't make it off the tarmac, and the adoption of some costly systems that were not properly vetted before the investment was made. There has been on occasion a history of disproportionately centralizing power in the hands of too few who, though well-intentioned, led to some bad turns and unnecessary waste. The university is, for the most part, aware of such conditions and is making efforts to rectify them by recruiting the right talent and building more substantial operational guard rails.

pros: I would like to take this opportunity to express my utmost appreciation and loyalty to Joyce University. As an employee, I have been fortunate enough to be a part of this institution for several years, and I can confidently say that it has been a transformative experience. From the moment I joined Joyce University, I have been impressed by the level of professionalism, commitment, and dedication of my colleagues. The university's leadership team has created a culture of inclusivity, respect, and excellence, which has enabled me to grow both personally and professionally. I have also had the opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds in academia, who have challenged me to expand my knowledge and skills. The university provides ample opportunities for professional development and encourages its employees to take on new challenges, which has been instrumental in my growth and career progression. Moreover, Joyce University values its employees' well-being and provides a supportive and nurturing work environment. The university offers comprehensive health and wellness benefits, flexible work arrangements, and a range of employee assistance programs. In summary, I cannot recommend Joyce University highly enough. It is a place where employees are valued, respected, and given the tools to succeed. I am proud to be a part of this institution and look forward to continuing my journey with Joyce University.
cons: Joyce University is so willing to give people chances that occasionally some people not in line with the values of the institution stay too long.

pros:
Joyce is a great place to "come to work" every day. They have openly embraced the transition by many employees, if their role allows for it, to a hybrid work model. They have a generous PTO policy which also helps enforce a positive work-life balance. (I think we're getting really good at respecting time off and allowing people to "take a break". It's quite exciting!) 

Joyce has prioritized investment in systems, processes and people. Expectations and goals of the organization are transparent and shared and discussed openly.

There is a strong sense of familial culture at Joyce. People genuinely like each other and there are lots of opportunities to contribute and engage.
cons: Growth and the frequent change that comes with it can be hard. It's not for everyone.

review_title: Ameritech is an Amazing Place to Work
pros: After more than two years at Ameritech I can honestly say the honeymoon is not over. The way they have kept us safe, both physically and emotionally, during the pandemic has not gone unappreciated by me and my peers. We have been encouraged to share our struggles and listen and care for others. We have not lost our sense of belonging during times of social distancing. We rally around shared purpose and the cohesiveness of our teams. I couldn't have imagined going through 2020 without trusting Ameritech as my anchor and am so grateful for the sense of security my employment there brings. I love so many of the people I work with and I know what a gift this all is. Ameritech's values are alive and well and I'm proud to aspire to them.
cons: There are some growing pains and sometimes it is hard to keep up with the continuous improvement initiatives. As far as "cons" go, I'll take this one.

review_title: A great place to challenge one's self and continuously seek positive growth.
pros: Ameritech is very people-centric and embraces diversity and inclusion. The benefits that are offered are outstanding and show that the health and wellness of the employees is very important to the company. Ameritech is focused and driven to reach their strategic goals and informs the employees how this will be achieved. Employees are allowed many opportunities to voice their concerns or needs through forums, meetings, one on one meetings with managers, performance reviews, and surveys. Ameritech is passionate about the continuous growth and projects many exciting new opportunities soon. There are many opportunities provided where employees can grow personally and professionally. These opportunities are robust and are great additions to any professional work portfolio.
cons: With the rapid growth, there are some growing pains. Additional work loads and challenges are placed upon many of the faculty and staff. It can be cumbersome to try to balance the new growth with the limited bandwidth of processes and technology systems. Additionally, the rapid growth is creating many new surprises for employees and students. Sometimes these surprises aren’t communicated to the correct parties in a timely manner. The main website is more promotional and brand material rather than detailed information of different departments, contact information, or other important information for current students. I.e. there is no quick links to the Academic Calendar, Canvas, Financial Aid, Advising, Student and Career Services, the Registrar’s Office and transcripts, general student information, etc.

The college seeks to offer unique educational experiences and is on a path to pioneering a new approach that will fundamentally change the way students learn and grow as healthcare providers by infusing diversity that will remove barriers and build bridges across the globe. This methodology is the right path for students that will undoubtedly inspire life long learning in our globally connected world.
cons: Parking is a challenge, but the college is dedicated to solving this issue and has a plan in motion.

review_title: Just saying it like it is
pros: I worked at AmeriTech College for 3 years and saw some great things and really great things done for students.
cons:
Where do I start?  The first is that most positive reviews (4+ stars) seem to come from the same marketing team (1 guy) or people that have been asked to write a positive review purely for marketing purposes.

Even when I still chat with the management that remains they have very little positive to say about the majority shareholder and the reason behind a lot of decisions he's making.

I read on glass door that someone thought their problems stemmed from embezzlement by the former CEO.  NOT TRUE!  He's a decent upstanding person and anyone in the company would still back that up.  There was just too much debt and still is at the college to allow for decisions to be made without that fact to sway operations.

Faculty and personnel only seem to be valued on how much money they can get away not paying them.

Hard build up PTO when they give very little each year.

Current career college climate makes this place an even harder world to live in.

pros: The best thing about the College is the students. These are hard-working people who deserve more ch better for the money they are paying
cons:
Where to start! The student population has doubled in the past two years (since the owner took over).. There is not adequate space for these students let alone space for faculty! We shared the tiniest office and most faculty had no space at all.  We were teaching a ridiculous number of sections of each course and we have no subs. 
The students have no idea when they sign up that they will not be getting great clinical training. Most of their clinical training is in “simulation” which is a great “supplement” to clinical training but is certainly not the way to be trained overall. And we know that good clinical training, particularly their capstone course is what leads to great jobs at graduation. What will happen when the College puts out graduates who cannot get jobs? 
It’s an absolute train wreck waiting to happen, which is why I left when I did!!

review_title: Nursing Program is Headed Downhill Fast
pros: Caring faculty who are simply trying to do their best with little resources
cons: The overall mood at the College has changed dramatically over the past few years.  It used to be a "family" who did what was best for the students.  Now it is much more about the number of students we can get and how much tuition they can pay.  Student complaints have grown 1000% due to the lack of faculty and gross lack of proper nursing training. Staff and faculty do their best but we can only do so much as we cannot meet the needs of the number of students.  One of my colleagues referred to it as a "diploma mill" as unfortunately, the college has lost its great reputation in the community.  We are all worried about students being able to find jobs and what the long-term consequences are of growing too fast, just to give all the money to the owner.  Truly sad what has happened and is continuing to happen.  If you are looking for work, this is not what it used to be.

review_title: It's a great place to work
pros: The College has undergone some massive changes in the last year and has new leadership to bring it out of a tough situation.  I love working with the people here and the focus is always on the student.  I see some of the negative reviews and I wonder if these are from employees who lost their jobs due to poor performance.  The College cannot afford to keep anyone who is not performing well and is unwilling to listen to ideas for improvement.
cons: Some mismanagement in the past has led to some financial distress; however, the turn-around over the last 12 months is very encouraging.  The health benefits are not as great as they once were, but there is hope that better health benefits will be back with increased financial security.

review_title: Great college with new management issues
pros: Great faculty and staff who love the students. Great pass rates and placement rates. Wonderful co-workers.
cons: New management is out of touch with what we do best. I'm afraid that we're going to end up in the same place as before with huge layoffs and furlough days. Ameritech seems to have lost it's direction with the new management and it doesn't seem to have the same feeling here with all the recent resignations from high up management positions. Honestly is there something they know that we don't?

pros: Located off a freeway (easy access), students who are dedicated to the hard work of the program, most of the nursing faculty. You can get $50 a month paid towards student loans.
cons: The building is not structured for a college. Parking is a nightmare. Very “top-heavy” administration and there is a high turnover of staff and other employees. Cliquish and not friendly. Very expensive to attend school if you’re a student (right around 60k for an associates degree). No raises for a long time (for faculty who do the work and teach 100 or more students in each cohort) but administration continue to get bonuses. They made it so you have to use PTO for what Ameritech designates as holidays, whether you want to or not. Academic calendar Ameritech created is a joke and students are frustrated because you don’t get breaks between semesters (2-3 days).

pros: What impresses me the most about Ameritech is the high level of education, experience, and natural talent of my coworkers. On top of that, they are an incredibly nice group of people. The more people I get to know, the more I realize what a privilege it is to work here.  I'm happy. I feel trusted and empowered to do my job and make a positive impact.
cons: The college has grown a lot, even in the few months I have been here, and few people are having a hard time adjusting to change.

pros: Ameritech has an amazing unlimited time off policy. They are also very understanding and considerate of their employees. Management has been making great changes to help the company be more employee centered. For example they have a great tuition payment benefits. I think the best part of Ameritechs management is that they have an open door policy. If needed you can walk directly into your manager's office, or even the CEO's office and talk to them about concerns.
cons: Some employees are very self centered. They don't understand or are willing to understand why changes are made. And they don't know how to advocate for themselves effectively.

pros: I see a lot of good things happening here. More accountability at every level, more financial transparency than before. Management seems to care about what we think. Raises are happening as promised.
cons: Healthcare is OK but could be better. Affordable healthcare plans are not a "perk" anymore they are necessary to stay competitive. I feel that we have gone through some challenging times but I do see things improving.

pros: Getting to know the people you work with here is very easy as long as you're willing. There are tons of events and get togethers that are optional to go to. Most everyone is willing to help on projects that aren't even in their job description simply because they want to see each other succeed.
cons: I've heard there are communication issues, not for me though. If I need something explained or I need to communicate something that isn't getting through, I just go talk to the person or people involved directly.

pros: Ameritech is a growing college that works to produce skilled graduates from their healthcare programs. These results are very noticeable with high pass rates on state exams.  (Higher than most all other colleges or universities in the state.)  The new Human Resources Department has worked tirelessly over the past year to implement many new resources for employees.  Better benefits have been put into place, paid time off has been enhanced, tuition reimbursement has been implemented, and a new employee recognition plan has produced great results.  The work atmosphere is more friendly and collegial now.  The new motto of "Assume Good Intent" is paying off.  The college is currently investing greatly in appropriate staffing and new equipment and supplies.  The new Simulation Center and Anatomy Lab will be a boon to the students.  Management is working to implement best practices and policies, build a stable environment, and listen to employee suggestions.  The company is more financially stable as a result, giving employees security in their jobs.  Because Ameritech is growing, job opportunities and employee development are plentiful.
cons: With the recent change to basically all administrative roles within the past year, the college has seen a large shift in vision and some protocols.  Because this shift occurred abruptly, employees had a large adjustment to make as well.  Trust in the process has been slow, but appears to be gaining momentum.  Communication has been a con, but with employee input and management's willingness to listen, this has also improved.  Sometimes current employees are not given a chance for advancement in lieu of attempts to find someone from outside the corporation.  Management needs to work on orientation programs for all positions.

pros: Supportive leadership; Ability to move up; Caring about students and staff/faculty, not just in the here and now, but in preparing for the future; Big picture thinking and positive vision.
cons: A lot of changes that I think will ultimately lead to a great program and place to work but there have been some bumps along the way. Those that don't have as much resilience may struggle more but things are settling down.

pros: The college talks a good game occasionally. They can get nursing students in the door pretty regularly. But they fluctuate a lot. Be careful. There were no pros when I left.
cons: You can't even rely on your salary here. They forced furlough when they couldn't pay us. Laid off a ton of employees. And tried to keep quiet about all the stuff happening in the company like embezzlement and other awful things. The college can't keep good employees. The ones that stay are playing a political game. You have a college that doesn't value education. Half the administrative staff, even managing staff have no college education and it shows. And yet the senior management goes around telling people that all these people are examples of not needing a degree...when we work in education. Half the problems are because the people in charge don't know how to face issues when they come up. They lay off educated people who try to fix a crumbling company. It's appalling. Management is failing and they take credit for your work under them and don't want to address any failures.  The last person says good change. If good change is a company preaching education but encourages employees to have no education by promoting poor performing employees that can talk a good talk. But can't deliver. Then sure. That school is going down the toilet quick. A lot of my coworkers were laid off and a lot of us quit. Because the environment is awful. Nobody listens to a non management employee because they believe in chain of command and the chain is so flawed I was threatened that id get fired if I talked about the flaws in our department to anyone above my manager. Seriously. It was toxic. I tell anyone who asks me my opinion not to go there. It is overpriced for what they offer and the students end up in more debt than they can handle. Do yourself a favor and find a real company.
